description:
Filobasidium floriforme is a species of fungus that belongs to the phylum Basidiomycota. It is a yeast-like organism that reproduces asexually through the formation of blastospores (budding cells).

Filobasidium floriforme is characterized by its ability to form flower-like structures, which are the result of the aggregation of blastospores. These floral structures are typically white or cream-colored and can be observed on the surface of various substrates, such as decaying wood or soil.

The cells of Filolobasidium floriforme are typically spherical or ovoid in shape and measure approximately 5-10 micrometers in diameter. The fungus is known to be ubiquitous in nature, with a global distribution.

Filobasidium floriforme is considered to be a saprophytic organism, meaning that it derives its nutrients from decaying organic matter. It plays a role in the decomposition of plant material and may contribute to nutrient cycling in natural ecosystems.

This species is not known to be pathogenic to humans or other organisms, and its ecological significance is primarily in its role as a decomposer in natural environments.
